H0.text: A protostar is what the Sun is most likely to become toward the end of its lifetime.

H1.text: A black hole is what the Sun is most likely to become toward the end of its lifetime.

H2.text: A neutron star is the most likely object the Sun will become toward the end of its lifetime.

H3.text: A white dwarf star is the most likely final state for the Sun toward the end of its lifetime.

A4.text: If the mass of a main‑sequence star is between 0.5 and 8 M☉, its core will become sufficiently hot to fuse helium into carbon and oxygen via the triple‑alpha process, but it will never become sufficiently hot to fuse neon.

A5.text: It will then expel most of its outer material to form a planetary nebula, leaving only the carbon–oxygen core.
